title: 115_s2018
content: The "American Family Act of 2017" establishes a fully refundable Child Tax Credit by eliminating the existing credit and inserting a new section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a fully refundable Child Tax Credit under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for a specified amount per qualifying child based on their age, with a limitation on the total credit amount. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a fully refundable Child Tax Credit under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for a specified amount per qualifying child based on their age, with a limitation on the total credit amount. The threshold amount for the modified adjusted gross income to qualify for the credit is $110,000 for joint filers, $75,000 for individuals, and $55,000 for married individuals filing separately. The Child Tax Credit introduced by the "American Family Act of 2017" provides a specified amount per qualifying child based on age, with a limit on the total credit amount. Marital status is determined under section 7703, and the applicable amount is calculated based on the number of qualifying children. A qualifying child is defined as one under 19 years of age. A qualifying child is defined as one under 19 years of age. The term 'qualifying child' excludes certain non-citizens and includes an inflation adjustment for taxable years after 2017. The Child Tax Credit requires the taxpayer to include the name and taxpayer identification number of the qualifying child on the tax return. The credit is not allowable for taxable years less than 12 months, except in cases of a taxpayer's death. No credit is allowed for taxpayers who improperly claimed it in prior years. The taxpayer's claim of credit under this section may be denied due to fraud, reckless or intentional disregard of rules and regulations. If denied, no credit shall be allowed for that taxable year. The taxpayer must provide necessary information to demonstrate eligibility for the credit. The credit allowed for a taxable year will be reduced by any advance payments received. If advance payments exceed the credit allowed, the tax for that year will be increased by the excess amount. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on advance payment of credit. "New section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for advance payment of child tax credit." The Secretary will establish a program for advance monthly payments of the child tax credit to eligible taxpayers, with limitations on the total amount per taxpayer for the taxable year. The program for advance monthly payments of the child tax credit will make efforts to apply the limitation of section 36C(b) with respect to payments made under the program. Conforming amendments will be made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing the item related to section 24 in subchapter A of chapter 1 of subtitle A. Additionally, the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A is updated by adding a new item after section 36B. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new item for the Child tax credit in section 36C. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item for the Child tax credit in section 36C. Amendments include advance payment of child tax credit, special rules for agreements with foreign affiliates, and adjustments to age requirements for tax benefits. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new Child tax credit in section 36C for individuals under 17 years of age. Various sections of the Code are amended to reflect this change, with the effective date starting after December 31, 2016.
